title: Norwegian Cruise Line, Netflix, Amazon.com: Stocks That Defined the Week

title: Aramco Strikes $12.4 Billion Oil Pipeline Deal With EIG-Led Group
summary: The move represents another far-reaching attempt to monetize Saudi Arabia’s prodigious oil assets—once considered so strategic that even a minority stake sale seemed far-fetched.

title: Don’t Be Fooled by the Market’s Newest Magic Trick
summary: A quirk in the calendar is doing some heavy lifting: The market declines from early last year just vanished from a key fund-manager benchmark.

title: Iran Releases South Korean Oil Tanker Seized Over Frozen Funds
summary: Banks in South Korea blocked several billion dollars in 2019 to comply with U.S. sanctions restricting financial transactions with Iran.

title: Mega Stocks Take Back Control of Market Rally
summary: For the past month, the “reflation trade” bet that a pumped-up economy would benefit riskiest assets the most has gone almost perfectly into reverse.

title: PE Daily: Better Banks $500 Million From SoftBank | Rubicon Founders Launches | Mercury Capital Fires Back
summary: Another week is nearly done and dusted! Some technology-enabled businesses continue to command eye-popping valuations as evidenced yesterday by SoftBank Group’s $500 million investment in online mortgage-lending company Better. SoftBank’s investment values the company at around $6 billion—more than 10 times its valuation in early 2019. If only the value of my home would appreciate that quickly.

title: Garcia’s Take: PE-Backed Oil Companies Can Still Find Value in Undrilled Land
summary: Pioneer Natural Resources, which recently agreed to buy private equity-backed DoublePoint Energy, said it was drawn both by the company’s production and its undeveloped acreage.

title: S&P 500 Hits Another Record as Tech Stocks Rally
summary: The broad U.S. stock benchmark notched its 19th record this year, propelled by a rally in big technology shares.

title: How an Obscure Fertilizer Deal Enriched a Mexican Billionaire
summary: After tycoon Ricardo Salinas Pliego used shell companies to gain control of a struggling firm called Fertinal from a government agency at a discount, his bank loaded it with high-interest debt and Mexican state oil giant Pemex acquired it for an inflated price.

title: As U.S. Economy Roars Back, Life in Many Poor Countries Gets Worse
summary: Powered by the U.S. and China, the global economy is set to make a stunning comeback this year. But for many developing countries the pandemic is still raging and poverty is deepening.

title: S&P 500 Edges Higher to Record
summary: Stocks were little changed after notes from the Federal Reserve’s last policy meeting showed that central bank officials reaffirmed their commitment to supporting the markets and the economy.

title: Biden Softens Tax Plan for Highly Profitable Businesses
summary: The administration’s $2 billion income threshold for a proposed 15% minimum tax on profitable companies that pay little would affect only an estimated 45 businesses.

title: PE Daily: ECP Seeks as Much as $1 Billion | Peak Rock Banks $2 Billion | CVC’s Toshiba Offer
summary: Data from the 451 Research unit of S&P Global Market Intelligence appear to back up the notion that the pandemic injected some adrenaline into global tech M&A as aggregate announced deal value rose to a record $302 billion in the first quarter. The frenzied level of blank-check activity also helped. But the number of deals during the period, at 850, was the second lowest for any quarter going back three years, with only last year’s pandemic-hit second quarter providing a lower number, at 789. That period’s total deal value fell to a paltry $36 billion. What a difference a year can make.

title: Shell Warns Oil-Price Gains Partly Offset by Hit From Texas Freeze
summary: Royal Dutch Shell said gains it made from higher oil prices in the first quarter would be partly offset by disruption related to the winter storm in Texas, knocking the energy giant’s recovery from the pandemic.

summary: What’s News: Business & Finance

title: Stocks Slip After Monday Records
summary: The S&P 500 edged slightly lower after strong economic data powered the benchmark gauge to its 17th all-time high of 2021 to start the week.

title: Dutch Police Arrest Suspect in Van Gogh Heist
summary: Police said the stolen artwork, “Parish Garden in Nuenen, Spring,” and another stolen painting, by Frans Hals, haven’t been located.

title: BP Signals Recovery for Oil Industry in Wake of Pandemic
summary: The oil giant said it had a solid start to the year, aided by higher energy prices and strong results from its trading division, giving the first indication that major oil companies are on the road to recovery after pandemic-induced losses across the industry last year.

title: Robert A. Mundell on Money: Wisdom of a Nobel Laureate (1932-2021)

summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 surged to records as a strong jobs report and data showing a rebound in the services sector cheered investors hoping for a robust economic recovery.

summary: The ambitious proposal to build out a network of electric vehicle charging stations could be a shot in the arm for the EV industry, but myriad legal, technical and budgetary problems need to be addressed.

summary: The massive natural-gas bills incurred during the Texas freeze have kicked off a spate of lawsuits around the country as companies argue over who is responsible for the tab.

summary: Updates on service-sector activity, trade and the global economic outlook highlight a relatively quiet week for economic data.

summary: U.S. worker productivity might be about to accelerate thanks to pandemic-induced technological adoption, which could lift economic growth and wages in coming years while staving off inflation pressure.

title: Pioneer’s $6.4 Billion Deal for Smaller Shale Rival Signals Life in Oil Patch
summary: The purchase of DoublePoint Energy is the largest for a privately held shale driller since 2011, underscoring recent momentum as oil tops $60 a barrel.

summary: Unfolding market conditions could lead to more value-oriented funds focused on environmental, social and governance issues.

title: OPEC, Allies Agree to Boost Output, Betting on Demand Rebound
summary: OPEC and an alliance of other top oil producers agreed to boost their collective production by more than two million barrels a day over coming months.

title: Copper Prices Retreat Alongside Popular Speculative Trades
summary: Copper could benefit from President Biden’s infrastructure plan, but some traders say any boost to demand has already been baked into prices.

title: First Phase of ‘Fedcoin’ Project This Fall; Biden Rolls Out $2.3 Trillion Infrastructure Blueprint
summary: Federal Reserve Bank of Boston and Massachusetts Institute of Technology researchers later this year should unveil the initial phase of a project that could produce a Federal Reserve digital dollar, which some have dubbed Fedcoin. Some regional Fed leaders are pushing back against the idea that very easy monetary policy is worsening economic inequality, which the central bank now aims to narrow with its policy-making regime. And President Biden unveiled his $2.3 trillion infrastructure plan.

title: Even Suez Canal Blockage Can’t Hold Back Red-Hot Global Trade
summary: Factories around the world are struggling to keep up with soaring demand for all types of goods as the global economic recovery from the pandemic accelerates.

title: What is...‘Jeopardy!’ Without Alex Trebek?
summary: The beloved quiz show has suffered from a string of uneven guest hosts and middling clues.

title: Return of Motorists Poised to Boost Corn Prices
summary: The higher demand expected for gasoline additive ethanol could boost corn prices that already have reached lofty levels on strong demand from China.

title: Newest Fed Governor Highlights Central Bank Independence
summary: Federal Reserve governor Christopher Waller used his first public speech to knock down the idea that the central bank could be pressured to make policy decisions to help the U.S. government run large deficits and finance its growing debt. “My goal today is to definitively put that narrative to rest,” the former research director of the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis said. He also said the Fed is unlikely to raise interest rates until the economy reaches the central bank’s goals on inflation and full employment, noting “We are a long ways from raising rates at this point.”

title: Suez Canal: How the Ship Blocking the Canal Was Freed
summary: For six days, the 1,300-foot vessel has blocked traffic, disrupting global supply chains and driving up the price of oil.

title: How to Bring Peace to the New Middle East
summary: Political shifts could resolve the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

title: New Mideast Crude Contract May Test OPEC’s Grip on Oil
summary: Abu Dhabi allowed trading of a futures contract linked to its flagship grade of crude for the first time in a debut that could test OPEC’s grip on oil prices.

title: High Tide in Suez Canal Raises Hopes of Freeing Cargo Ship
summary: Specialists are hoping that a higher-than-usual spring tide will help them unstick the 1,300-foot Ever Given from the east side of the channel.

title: China Helped Rev Up, and Then Slow Down, the Commodities Boom
summary: Nearly a yearlong bull run among industrial metals is faltering as the unwinding of a stimulus in China slows demand, underscoring the increasingly pivotal role its state-led economy plays in global commodity booms.

title: How Suez Canal Ship Caused Global Supply Traffic Jam
summary: The initial probe into the blockage by the Ever Given focuses on a seasonal sandstorm and a sudden burst of wind.

summary: Natural gas, long seen long seen by energy companies as a bridge between fossil fuels and renewables, faces growing environmental scrutiny and competition from cleaner energy sources.

summary: A strong Friday finish for the broad benchmark pushed it and the Dow industrials to new highs, while tech stocks and Nasdaq trailed behind.

title: What’s Wrong With Global Supply Chains and How It Affects You
summary: An imbalance in semiconductor supply and demand, a freeze in Texas in February, a grounded ship in the Suez Canal and other problems collectively have limited the availability of key materials to manufacturers world-wide.

title: Suez Canal Blockage Sends Exporters Scrambling
summary: Asian and European manufacturers, which rely heavily on the Suez Canal to move their products between regions, are weighing contingency plans as efforts to move a ship drag out.

title: Iranian Politicians Divided on Return to Nuclear Talks With U.S.
summary: The split reflects disagreements over how long Iran can withstand the economic damage inflicted by sanctions and jockeying ahead of presidential elections in June, making it hard to predict when and under what conditions Iran would be willing to meet with the U.S.

title: Egypt Expanded the Suez Canal. It Wasn’t Enough.
summary: The canal expansion was supposed to boost shipping traffic, earn more revenue for Egypt and bolster Egyptian President Abdel Fattah Al Sisi’s global stature. Instead the president is mired in one of the biggest crises of his seven-year rule.

title: PE Daily: Hopes for Energy Exits | Labor Activists Put BlueSky in Crosshairs | Ara Partners Seeks $650 Million | WeWork Agrees to SPAC Deal
summary: Happy Friday Pro PE readers! Yesterday, the House Ways and Means Committee’s oversight subcommittee held a hearing on private-equity’s expanded role in healthcare that seemed to focus mainly on the industry’s ownership of nursing homes and what the witnesses said is a need for increased transparency into the operations and finances of private equity-owned nursing homes. Witnesses included a business school professor, a healthcare workers union leader along with other healthcare advocates, but no one from the private-equity industry itself. And not much in the way of actual data presented from what I can tell. But stay tuned as I sense that Congress is just getting warmed up on this one.

title: WeWork, GameStop, AMC, Nucor: What to Watch When the Market Opens
summary: S&P 500 futures rise, pointing to further gains when markets open Friday

title: Powell Says Debt Is Manageable; Bostic in No Rush to Change Policy; Evans Sees 2024 Rate Rise; Payout Restrictions to End for Most Banks
summary: Jerome Powell said that the federal government can manage its debt at current levels but fiscal-policy makers should seek to slow its growth once the economy is stronger. Meanwhile, Atlanta Fed President Raphael Bostic said he sees no reason to pare monetary policy support for the economy, and Chicago Fed leader Charles Evans said it may be three more years before the Fed raises its short-term interest rate target. And the Fed said temporary limits on dividend payments and share buybacks will end for most banks after June 30.

title: Higher Oil Prices Renew Exit Hopes for PE-Backed Energy Companies
summary: Publicly traded energy companies, once among the biggest buyers of their private equity-backed peers, became less acquisitive in recent years as they faced shareholder pressure to be more disciplined with their capital. But this year’s rally in oil-and-gas prices and a rebound in energy stocks are giving private-equity investors some renewed hope.

title: Energy Industry Grapples With Fallout From Suez Canal Blockage
summary: The fallout from the Suez Canal blockage rippled through the energy industry, with the cost of renting tankers rising and shippers starting to plot alternative routes for supplies of oil and gas.

title: Oil Lobby Backs Climate Action Plan
summary: ‘Climate change is real,’ American Petroleum Institute head Mike Sommers says.

title: Powell Says Rising Bond Yields a Sign of Upbeat Economic Outlook; Homeowners in Europe Are Paid to Borrow
summary: Jerome Powell told lawmakers he is taking the rise in long-term bond yields in stride, noting that yields have increased from “extraordinarily low levels.” Meanwhile, New York Fed leader John Williams said central bank policy is helping position the U.S. economy for a robust recovery, while San Francisco Fed chief Mary Daly said monetary policy shouldn’t be changed in reaction to theoretical threats of inflation. And the pandemic is pushing benchmark interest rates deeper into negative territory in Europe, widening the pool of mortgage holders who receive interest.

title: Suez Canal Is Blocked by Container Ship Causing Huge Traffic Jam

summary: The U.A.E. is hoping to attract high-end tourists with a live cultural event while the art world watches to see who shows up.

title: Pro Bankruptcy Briefing: Lawmakers Target Chapter 11 Releases; Diehard Film Fans Still Love Big Screen; Will Travel Come Back?
summary: Congressional Democrats proposed legislation that would reign in bankruptcy courts’ ability to sign away the government’s claims against third parties, such as the Sackler family members who own OxyContin maker Purdue Pharma. Film buffs flocked into Los Angeles-area theaters, testing Hollywood executives’ predictions that big-city markets’ reopening would revive the movie business. And Americans are looking to get out of town after a year of virus-related restrictions that have hobbled the travel business.

title: Oil Giant Aramco’s Shares Remain a Curiosity
summary: While Aramco will likely continue to play its role as the central banker of oil, its stock-market listing is more a curiosity than a reality for global investors.

title: Fed Ending Emergency Capital Relief; Turkish Lira Falls After Central Bank Chief’s Ouster; Powell Vows Fed Support for Recovery
summary: The Fed on Friday ended a yearlong reprieve that had eased capital requirements for big banks, a move that could ripple through markets, and may, as Greg Ip writes, work against the central bank’s efforts to support the economic recovery. Writing in the WSJ opinion pages, Jerome Powell said the Fed will continue providing its support for as long as necessary. And the Turkish lira fell sharply after the abrupt ouster of the country’s central bank chief, a move that followed a rate-hike and stoked concern that inflation will accelerate.

title: Even Jil Sander Doesn't Know The Secret To Buying Clothes From Her Hit Uniqlo Collaboration
summary: Ahead of the new +J launch on March 25, the designer tells us about the new collection and what she thinks of eBay resales

title: Turkey’s New Central Bank Head Seeks to Reassure Markets
summary: Sahap Kavcioglu, who was named to the post late Friday after his predecessor was abruptly fired, said the bank’s main objective is to achieve “a permanent fall in inflation.”

title: Turkey’s Erdogan Ousts Central Bank Governor in Surprise Move
summary: Naci Agbal is the third central bank chief fired by President Recep Tayyip Erdogan in less than two years, as the country has weathered a series of economic and geopolitical crises.

summary: Companies are touting straws and bottles made from a plant-based plastic, but researchers say some claims are overstated.

summary: The case was the first successful extradition of a North Korean by the U.S., experts said, and could strengthen Washington’s hand in enforcing sanctions.

summary: Rising oil shipments to China followed President Biden’s offer of relief to Iran in return for the country’s compliance with an international nuclear agreement and to Venezuela if it organized free elections, officials said.

summary: The three tech giants now collect more than half of all ad dollars spent in the U.S. The pandemic economy got them there.

summary: Oil prices fell more than 7% on Thursday, recording their biggest one-day drop since September as traders weighed signs that demand in Europe could falter and data showing that crude remains plentiful.

title: Pro Bankruptcy Briefing: Boy Scout Councils Feel Pressure; Intelsat Equity Denied Official Voice; Nine Point Energy Kicks Off Sale
summary: The Boy Scouts of America’s local councils made concessions to restore a legal ceasefire as a bankruptcy judge lamented the $100 million legal bill from the organization’s chapter 11. Intelsat shareholders didn’t get traction on their bid for an official voice in negotiations, and Nine Point Energy Holdings began a chapter 11 sale process.

title: Supply Chain Woes Slam Global Manufacturing
summary: The extreme weather in Texas and backlogs at California ports have compounded problems during the pandemic by slowing production and supplies for a range of businesses.

summary: Brazil became the first major economy to raise interest rates this year, a harbinger for other developing countries that could be forced to raise borrowing costs and endanger their fragile economies.

title: CFTC Creates Climate Risk Unit to Review Futures, Options
summary: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission formed a new unit to gauge the dangers posed by climate change to futures and options markets, the latest move by a financial regulator related to climate change under the Biden administration.

title: Dow Closes Above 33000 for First Time
summary: The record comes just five trading days after the blue-chip average first closed above than 32000—its quickest 1,000-point milestone on record.

title: Gasoline Demand Has Peaked, Global Forecaster Says
summary: The world’s thirst for gasoline isn’t likely to return to pre-pandemic levels, the International Energy Agency forecast, calling a peak for the fuel that has powered personal transportation for more than a century.

title: Carbon Capture Is Key to Companies’ Net Zero Pledges
summary: Many companies’ plans to reduce their greenhouse-gas emissions to “net zero” rely heavily on technologies to capture carbon. Some are more speculative than others.

title: New Houses Are Costing More as Prices Jump for Wood, Bricks
summary: Prices are surging for construction materials, and builders are passing the costs to home buyers as demand remains high.

title: Dow, S&P 500 Pull Back From Record Levels
summary: A morning rally in technology shares lost steam, with the Nasdaq Composite giving up much of its early gains and the Dow and S&P 500 closing lower.

title: British Financier Alan Howard Is the Buyer of Vincent Viola’s New York Townhouse
summary: The 20,000-square-foot, roughly 40-foot-wide mansion sold for $59 million.

title: Stephen Bechtel, Head of Family Construction Firm for Three Decades, Dies at Age 95
summary: Stephen D. Bechtel Jr., who expanded the global reach of his family’s giant engineering and construction company as chief executive from 1960 to 1990, died Monday.

title: Putting the Risk Into Risk-Free Treasurys
summary: Buyers have concluded that locking up their money in U.S. government bonds for a decade or more is now riskier than before.

title: Pro Bankruptcy Briefing: Purdue Owners Boost Settlement Offer; Texas Power Retailer Griddy Files for Bankruptcy; HighPoint Reorganizing Ahead of Merger
summary: The Sackler family is upping its offer to settle lawsuits that OxyContin maker Purdue Pharma has been facing. Griddy Energy is seeking protection from creditors while trying to provide relief for former customers hurt by Texas’s winter storm. HighPoint Resources filed for bankruptcy, hoping the chapter 11 smooths the way for a merger with another oil-and-gas operator.

title: Fed Expected to Note Brighter Outlook for Jobs, Inflation; Weighing the Fed’s Yield-Control Options
summary: Fed officials could raise their forecasts for growth and inflation and lower their unemployment projections at their meeting this week, but they are expected to stress that it is too early to change their plans for interest rates and bond purchases. Meanwhile, Michael S. Derby takes a look at the strategies the central bank could turn to should it decide to lean on long-term Treasury yields.

title: Demographic Differences Found in Inflation Expectations
summary: A person’s age is a key driver of expectations about inflation, economists at Deutsche Bank said in a report Monday.

title: Not-So Supertankers Deserve a Look as Pandemic Fades

title: Commodities Supercycle Looks Like a Stretch
summary: Some investors are betting commodity prices will surge over a long period, but history suggests the conditions aren’t right.

title: Value Investors Finally Have Reason to Celebrate—for Now
summary: As the rollout of Covid-19 vaccines quickens and the economy bounces back from last year’s shutdowns, portfolio managers are snapping up shares of cyclical companies.

title: ECB to Speed Up Bond Buying; Bank of Canada Backs Monetary Support; Biden Signs $1.9 Trillion Relief Bill; Fedspeak Cheat Sheet
summary: The European Central Bank will accelerate its bond buying as it seeks to contain rising borrowing costs that have concerned officials. President Christine Lagarde said the increase in bond yields in part reflected higher growth expectations in the U.S.—helped by the stimulus package just signed into law by President Biden—rather than a recovery in Europe. Meanwhile, Bank of Canada Deputy Gov. Lawrence Schembri said the Canadian economy continues to require extraordinary monetary policy support. And, in advance of the Federal Reserve policy meeting next week, we round up what Fed officials have been saying since their last meeting.

title: Antitrust Law and Why Congress Wants to Change It
summary: Democrats and Republicans are now considering the most significant changes in decades to a regimen that dates back more than 130 years and affects every part of the economy.

summary: A growing wave of fiscal stimulus and the continuing rollout of coronavirus vaccinations are helping to brighten this year’s outlooks for economic growth and oil demand, the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries said.

title: PE Daily: BlackRock Nets $3.7 Billion for Renewables | 325 Capital Takes Off | Riverside Builds a Continuation Fund
summary: It’s interesting to see that technology stocks went unloved on Wednesday even as the Dow 30 soared some 464 points to close at a fresh record. Interesting because so many private-equity firms (and blank-check companies) are targeting the sector for investment, and by most accounts valuations are sky high and going higher. As one strategist told the Journal’s Will Horner and Paul Vigna, with inflation concerns and an expected economic rebound accelerating, gains in U.S. stocks may be “limited from here.”

title: GameStop, AMC, Bumble: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today
summary: The number of Americans applying for jobless benefits declined.

title: Shell Appoints New Chairman to Navigate Energy Transition
summary: Shell has appointed Andrew Mackenzie as its new chairman, tapping a mining veteran to oversee the oil and gas giant as it navigates the transition to low-carbon energy.

summary: The $1.9 trillion spending bill is only a taste of what’s coming.

title: Crude-Oil Price Overhaul Hits Delay Amid Shipping-Cost Uproar
summary: Platts defers its plan to include West Texas oil prices in its basket of international crudes following pushback from the industry over the handling of freight costs.

title: Has Carbon Pricing’s Time Finally Arrived?
summary: We’ve all seen how ineffective many regulations are and how inefficient the regulatory seesaw of executive action is. Now is the time to get reasonable carbon pricing enacted.

title: Pro Bankruptcy Briefing: Crypto Firm Executive Pegged as Fugitive; Texas Crisis Bankrupts Power Retailer; Seadrill Launches Talks
summary: A former top executive at cryptocurrency platform Cred has a troubling past, according to a probe into how and why the firm collapsed. A second major bankruptcy was filed over the Texas energy crisis. And offshore rig operator Seadrill is at a crossroads in its bankruptcy.

title: Sundance Energy Files for Chapter 11 Bankruptcy
summary: The onshore oil-and-gas company said it reached an agreement with lenders to bolster its balance sheet and pare its debt load by $250 million.
